PostgreSQL: Widely used open source RDBMS Developed as objectoriented DBMS (Postgres), gradually enhanced with 'standards' like SQL
MongoDB: One of the most popular document stores available both as a fully managed cloud service and for deployment on self-managed infrastructure
IBM Db2: Common in IBM host environments, 2 different versions for host and Windows/Linux
Redis: In-memory data structure store, used as database, cache and message broker Redis focuses on performance so most of its design decisions prioritize high performance and very low latencies.
Elasticsearch: A distributed, RESTful modern search and analytics engine based on Apache Lucene Elasticsearch lets you perform and combine many types of searches such as structured, unstructured, geo, and metric
Microsoft Access: Microsoft Access combines a backend RDBMS (JET / ACE Engine) with a GUI frontend for data manipulation and queries. The Access frontend is often used for accessing other datasources (DBMS, Excel, etc.)
Cassandra: Wide-column store based on ideas of BigTable and DynamoDB Optimized for write access
MariaDB: MySQL application compatible open source RDBMS, enhanced with high availability, security, interoperability and performance capabilities. MariaDB ColumnStore provides a column-oriented storage engine and MariaDB Xpand supports distributed SQL.
Hive: data warehouse software for querying and managing large distributed datasets, built on Hadoop
Teradata: A hybrid cloud data analytics software platform (Teradata Vantage)
Microsoft Azure SQL Database: Database as a Service offering with high compatibility to Microsoft SQL Server
Amazon DynamoDB: Hosted, scalable database service by Amazon with the data stored in Amazons cloud
SAP Adaptive Server: The SAP (Sybase) Adaptive Server Enterprise (ASE) is an enterprise-class RDBMS
SAP HANA: In-memory, column based data store. Available as appliance or cloud service

MySQL: Relational DBMS Key/Value like access via memcached API
PostgreSQL: Relational DBMS with object oriented extensions, e.g.: user defined types/functions and inheritance. Handling of key/value pairs with hstore module.
MongoDB: Document store
IBM Db2: Relational DBMS Since Version 10.5 support for JSON/BSON documents compatible with MongoDB
Redis: Key-value store Multiple data types and a rich set of operations, as well as configurable data expiration, eviction and persistence

MongoDB: Spatial DBMSSearch engine integrated Lucene index, currently in MongoDB Atlas only.
IBM Db2: Document storeRDF store in Db2 LUW (Linux, Unix, Windows)Spatial DBMS with Db2 Spatial Extender
Redis: Document store with Redis ModulesGraph DBMS with Redis ModulesSpatial DBMSSearch engine with Redis ModulesTime Series DBMS with Redis Modules
MariaDB: Document storeGraph DBMS with OQGraph storage engineSpatial DBMS
Teradata: Document storeGraph DBMSSpatial DBMSTime Series DBMS
SAP Adaptive Server: Spatial DBMS with Boeing's Spatial Query Server
SAP HANA: Document storeGraph DBMS with SAP Hana, Enterprise EditionSpatial DBMS

MySQL: Oracle since 2010, originally MySQL AB, then Sun
MongoDB: MongoDB, Inc
Redis: Salvatore Sanfilippo Development sponsored by Redis Labs
Cassandra: Apache Software Foundation Apache top level project, originally developped by Facebook
MariaDB: MariaDB Corporation Ab (MariaDB Enterprise), MariaDB Foundation (community MariaDB Server) The lead developer Monty Widenius is the original author of MySQL
Hive: Apache Software Foundation initially developed by Facebook

MongoDB: 4.4.4 , February 2021

Oracle: commercial restricted free version is available
MySQL: Open Source GPL version 2. Commercial licenses with extended functionallity are available
Microsoft SQL Server: commercial restricted free version is available
MongoDB: Open Source MongoDB Inc.'s Server Side Public License v1. Prior versions were published under GNU AGPL v3.0. Commercial licenses are also available.
Redis: Open Source BSD 3-Clause, commercial license available
Elasticsearch: Open Source Apache Version 2; Elastic License
MariaDB: Open Source GPL version 2, commercial enterprise subscription available
Splunk: commercial Limited free edition and free developer edition available
Amazon DynamoDB: commercial free tier for a limited amount of database operations
Neo4j: Open Source GPL version3, commercial licenses available

Features: Cloud-based only Only available as a cloud service
MongoDB: no MongoDB available as DBaaS (MongoDB Atlas)
SAP HANA: no also available as a cloud based service

Features: DBaaS offerings (sponsored links) Database as a ServiceProviders of DBaaS offerings, please contact us to be listed.

MongoDB: LinuxOS XSolarisWindows
Redis: BSDLinuxOS XWindows ported and maintained by Microsoft Open Technologies, Inc.
Elasticsearch: All OS with a Java VM
Microsoft Access: Windows Not a real database server, but making use of DLLs
MariaDB: FreeBSDLinuxSolarisWindows ColumnStore storage engine not available on Windows
Hive: All OS with a Java VM
Neo4j: Linux Can also be used server-less as embedded Java database.OS XSolarisWindows

Oracle: yes Schemaless in JSON and XML columns
MongoDB: schema-free Although schema-free, documents of the same collection often follow the same structure. Optionally impose all or part of a schema by defining a JSON schema.
Elasticsearch: schema-free Flexible type definitions. Once a type is defined, it is persistent

Features: Typing predefined data types such as float or date
MongoDB: yes string, integer, double, decimal, boolean, date, object_id, geospatial
Redis: partial Supported data types are strings, hashes, lists, sets and sorted sets, bit arrays, hyperloglogs and geospatial indexes
SQLite: yes not rigid because of 'dynamic typing' concept.

Features: XML support Some form of processing data in XML format, e.g. support for XML data structures, and/or support for XPath, XQuery or XSLT.
PostgreSQL: yes specific XML-type available, but no XML query functionality.

MongoDB: yes
Elasticsearch: yes All search fields are automatically indexed
Cassandra: restricted only equality queries, not always the best performing solution
Teradata: yes Join-index to prejoin tables, aggregate index, sparse index, hash index
Neo4j: yes pluggable indexing subsystem, by default Apache Lucene

MongoDB: Read-only SQL queries via the MongoDB Connector for BI
SQLite: yes SQL-92 is not fully supported
Microsoft Access: yes but not compliant to any SQL standard
Cassandra: SQL-like SELECT, DML and DDL statements (CQL)
Splunk: no Splunk Search Processing Language for search commands

PostgreSQL: ADO.NETJDBCnative C libraryODBCstreaming API for large objects
MongoDB: proprietary protocol using JSON
Redis: proprietary protocol RESP - REdis Serialization Protocol
SQLite: ADO.NET inofficial driverJDBC inofficial driverODBC inofficial driver
Cassandra: Proprietary protocol CQL (Cassandra Query Language, an SQL-like language)Thrift
Neo4j: Bolt protocolCypher query languageJava APINeo4j-OGM Object Graph MapperRESTful HTTP APISpring Data Neo4jTinkerPop 3

MongoDB: Actionscript unofficial driverCC#C++Clojure unofficial driverColdFusion unofficial driverD unofficial driverDart unofficial driverDelphi unofficial driverErlangGoGroovy unofficial driverHaskellJavaJavaScriptLisp unofficial driverLua unofficial driverMatLab unofficial driverPerlPHPPowerShell unofficial driverProlog unofficial driverPythonR unofficial driverRubyRustScalaSmalltalk unofficial driverSwift

Oracle: PL/SQL also stored procedures in Java possible
Microsoft SQL Server: Transact SQL, .NET languages, R, Python and (with SQL Server 2019) Java
PostgreSQL: user defined functions realized in proprietary language PL/pgSQL or with common languages like Perl, Python, Tcl etc.
MongoDB: JavaScript
Microsoft Access: yes since Access 2010 using the ACE-engine
MariaDB: yes PL/SQL compatibility added with version 10.3
Hive: yes user defined functions and integration of map-reduce
Teradata: yes UDFs, stored procedures, table functions in parallel
Neo4j: yes User defined Procedures and Functions

MongoDB: yes in MongoDB Atlas only
Redis: no publish/subscribe channels provide limited trigger functionality
Microsoft Access: yes since Access 2010 using the ACE-engine
Amazon DynamoDB: yes by integration with AWS Lambda

Features: Partitioning methods Methods for storing different data on different nodes
MySQL: horizontal partitioning, sharding with MySQL Cluster or MySQL Fabric
Microsoft SQL Server: tables can be distributed across several files (horizontal partitioning); sharding through federation
PostgreSQL: partitioning by range, list and (since PostgreSQL 11) by hash
MongoDB: Sharding partitioned by hashed, ranged, or zoned sharding keys
MariaDB: several options for horizontal partitioning and Sharding

Features: Replication methods Methods for redundantly storing data on multiple nodes
Microsoft SQL Server: yes, but depending on the SQL-Server Edition
PostgreSQL: Source-replica replication other methods possible by using 3rd party extensions
MongoDB: Multi-Source deployments with MongoDB Atlas Global ClustersSource-replica replication
Redis: Multi-source replication with Redis Enterprise PackSource-replica replication Chained replication is supported
Cassandra: selectable replication factor Representation of geographical distribution of servers is possible
Neo4j: Causal Clustering using Raft protocol available in in Enterprise Version only

Features: MapReduce Offers an API for user-defined Map/Reduce methods
Oracle: no can be realized in PL/SQL
MongoDB: yes
Amazon DynamoDB: no may be implemented via Amazon Elastic MapReduce (Amazon EMR)

Features: Consistency concepts Methods to ensure consistency in a distributed system
MongoDB: Eventual ConsistencyImmediate Consistency can be individually decided for each write operation
Redis: Eventual ConsistencyStrong eventual consistency with CRDTs
Elasticsearch: Eventual Consistency Synchronous doc based replication. Get by ID may show delays up to 1 sec. Configurable write consistency: one, quorum, all
Cassandra: Eventual ConsistencyImmediate Consistency can be individually decided for each write operation
Amazon DynamoDB: Eventual ConsistencyImmediate Consistency can be specified for read operations
Neo4j: Causal and Eventual Consistency configurable in Causal Cluster setupImmediate Consistency in stand-alone mode

MySQL: yes not for MyISAM storage engine
MongoDB: no typically not used, however similar functionality with DBRef possible
MariaDB: yes not for MyISAM storage engine

Features: Transaction concepts Support to ensure data integrity after non-atomic manipulations of data
Oracle: ACID isolation level can be parameterized
MySQL: ACID not for MyISAM storage engine
MongoDB: Multi-document ACID Transactions with snapshot isolation
Redis: Optimistic locking, atomic execution of commands blocks and scripts
Microsoft Access: ACID but no files for transaction logging
Cassandra: no Atomicity and isolation are supported for single operations
MariaDB: ACID not for MyISAM storage engine
Splunk: no A 'Transaction' in Splunk has a different meaning: grouping related events into a single one for later searching
Amazon DynamoDB: ACID ACID across one or more tables within a single AWS account and region

Features: Concurrency Support for concurrent manipulation of data
MySQL: yes table locks or row locks depending on storage engine
MongoDB: yes
Redis: yes Data access is serialized by the server

Features: Durability Support for making data persistent
MongoDB: yes optional
Redis: yes Configurable mechanisms for persistency via snapshots and/or operations logs
Microsoft Access: yes but no files for transaction logging
MariaDB: yes not for in-memory storage engine

Features: In-memory capabilities Is there an option to define some or all structures to be held in-memory only.
Oracle: yes Version 12c introduced the new option 'Oracle Database In-Memory'
MongoDB: yes In-memory storage engine introduced with MongoDB version 3.2

Oracle: fine grained access rights according to SQL-standard
MySQL: Users with fine-grained authorization concept no user groups or roles
Microsoft SQL Server: fine grained access rights according to SQL-standard
PostgreSQL: fine grained access rights according to SQL-standard
MongoDB: Access rights for users and roles
IBM Db2: fine grained access rights according to SQL-standard
Redis: Simple password-based access control Access control lists and SSL are available in the commercial version
Microsoft Access: no a simple user-level security was built in till version Access 2003
Cassandra: Access rights for users can be defined per object
MariaDB: fine grained access rights according to SQL-standard
Splunk: Access rights for users and roles
Hive: Access rights for users, groups and roles
Teradata: fine grained access rights according to SQL-standard
Microsoft Azure SQL Database: fine grained access rights according to SQL-standard
Amazon DynamoDB: Access rights for users and roles can be defined via the AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM)
Neo4j: Users, roles and permissions. Pluggable authentication with supported standards (LDAP, Active Directory, Kerberos)
SAP Adaptive Server: fine grained access rights according to SQL-standard
